[[University of Cambridge]] | alma_mater = [[Edinburgh University]]
[[Cambridge University]]
[[University College London]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Karl Pearson]] | doctoral_students = [[M. S. Bartlett]] }} '''John Wishart''' {{Post-nominals|post-noms=[[Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh|FRSE]]}} (28 November 1898 – 14 July 1956) was a Scottish mathematician and agricultural statistician. He worked successively at [[University College London]] with [[Karl Pearson]], at [[Rothamsted Experimental Station]] with [[Ronald Fisher]], and then as a leader in statistics in the [[University of Cambridge]] where he became the first Director of the [[Statistical Laboratory, University of Cambridge|Statistical Laboratory]] in 1953. He was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] in 1931,{{cite book |last1=Waterston |first1=Charles D |last2=Macmillan Shearer |first2=A |title=Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783-2002: Biographical Index |url=http://www.rse.org.uk/fellowship/fells_indexp2.pdf |accessdate=5 February 2011 |volume=II |date=July 2006 |publisher=[[The Royal Society of Edinburgh]] |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-0-902198-84-5}} and edited ''[[Biometrika (journal)|Biometrika]]'' from 1937. The [[Wishart distribution]] is named after him. Wishart died at age 57 in a bathing accident in [[Acapulco]] while representing the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] on a mission to set up a research centre. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{Cite web | first1=P. | last1=Whittle | title = The Cambridge Statistical Laboratory up to 1993 (revised 2002) | url=http://www.statslab.cam.ac.uk/History/2history.html | postscript=}} * {{MacTutor Biography|id=Wishart|title=John Wishart}} *[http://www-history.mcs.st-andrews.ac.uk/Obits/Wishart.html Times Obituary] *{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/biomet/44.1-2.1 |title=John Wishart 1898–1956 |year=1957 |author=Pearson, E.
